awd_abstract_narration:
Three-manifolds are objects modeled on the three-dimensional space that we live in.  A donut and the spatial universe are both examples of three-manifolds. These objects arise naturally in many contexts in physical and other natural sciences, and can be used to model many interesting phenomena. The main goal of this project is to study the mathematical properties of three-manifolds. The PI plans to investigate some central questions in a branch of mathematics, known as low dimensional topology. These questions are concerned with how three-manifolds change under certain maps as well as operations called surgeries. The major tool that the PI uses is a topological structure called Heegaard splitting, which is a decomposition of a complicated three-manifold into simpler pieces along a two-dimensional surface. This research targets some of the fundamental questions in low-dimensional topology and knot theory. It also has a potential impact on other areas of scientific investigations, such as the topological structures of DNA.
 
In this project, the PI will study the topology of three-manifolds. The project has three major parts. The first part is to explore a new approach to proving the Berge Conjecture. The Berge Conjecture can be divided into two halves: the first half is to prove the Berge Conjecture for knots with tunnel number one, and the second half is to show that if a nontrivial knot in the three-sphere admits a lens-space Dehn surgery, then the knot must have tunnel number one. The PI and his collaborators have carried out an in-depth study on the first half. The same approach may lead to a proof of the second half of the Berge Conjecture. The second part of the research is to study a long-standing conjecture concerning Heegaard genus and degree-one map. The PI will investigate this conjecture using special type of surgeries. The objective of the last part of the research is to study several fundamental questions in three-manifold topology concerning Heegaard splittings and curve complex. The PI plans to develop new tools and use techniques from his previous work to achieve these goals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project, funded by the NSF, aims to advance research in low-dimensional topology, a branch of mathematics that studies the fundamental shape and intrinsic properties of geometric objects. Topological concepts are central to many areas of mathematics today. A key object of study in topology is called "manifold," a shape that, while possibly complex as a whole, resembles flat, familiar Euclidean space when viewed up close. For example, a 2-dimensional manifold is simply a surface, while a 3-dimensional manifold (or 3-manifold) has the added depth of an additional dimension. 

The study of 3-manifolds has generated considerable interest due to their intricate geometric and combinatorial structures and because many questions about them remain unanswered. Understanding these structures not only advances the fields of geometry and topology but could also have significant implications in the physical sciences and other natural sciences.

Researchers use a variety of techniques to analyze complicated 3-manifolds. One geometric method is to decompose a 3-manifold into collections of 2-dimensional surfaces, such as "taut foliations," which organize the manifold in ways that make its structure easier to understand. Algebraic methods are also valuable, particularly the study of "fundamental groups" and various homology theories, which provide algebraic data that describes a manifold's properties.

A major open question in low-dimensional topology is the L-space Conjecture, which suggests that three seemingly unrelated properties of 3-manifolds are actually equivalent. One part of this conjecture proposes that a generic 3-manifold has a taut foliation if and only if its fundamental group—a separate algebraic structure—can be "left-orderable" (ordered in a certain way). The PI contributed to this question by using a different geometric structure called Heegaard splittings and demonstrated the equivalence between taut foliations and left-orderable fundamental groups for 3-manifolds with a particular type of Heegaard splitting. This result was published in the Duke Mathematical Journal.

Qingfeng Lyu, a Ph.D. student supervised by the PI and partially supported by this NSF grant, made significant progress on a conjecture related to the L-space Conjecture. This conjecture, proposed by Boyer, Gordon, and Hu, suggests that certain slopes in knots within a 3-dimensional sphere can reveal the presence of taut foliations. Lyu successfully proved this for a specific type of knot called (1,1)-knots, adding new insights to this area of topology.

The PI also addressed another prominent question, the Berge Conjecture. This conjecture says that if a knot in the 3-dimensional sphere has a lens-space surgery (a particular type of 3-manifold transformation), then the knot must be from a specific set of known knots identified by John Berge. The PI and collaborators made a significant breakthrough in this area by proving that the Berge Conjecture holds for all knots that can be unknotted by a single tunnel, a category that includes all Berge knots. This work, a lengthy and technical paper, underwent major revisions during the grant period. Additionally, the PI has made further progress on the remaining aspects of the Berge Conjecture.

This project also served as a platform to train junior graduate students. The PI organized summer reading and research programs at Boston College, and shared findings from this research in lectures at conferences and seminars. Through this NSF-funded project, the PI continues to deepen our understanding of 3-manifolds, addressing some of the most challenging and influential questions in low-dimensional topology.
